org.macquarie.head
Class Sprite

java.lang.Object
  org.macquarie.head.Sprite

public class Sprite
extends java.lang.Object

This class is used to represent simple "sprites", that is the animatable images that make up an animated image.

In this case, all sprites are drawn as instances of the same image. A sprite knows its current location and its velocity. This latter information tells the sprite the direction it should move in and the speed at which it will move. This is expressed pixel increments or decrements in the x and y directions.

Each sprite knows how to update it location and velocity from one frame to the next (the step() method) and how to draw itself on a Graphics object (the paint() method).

Author:
Dominic Verity

Method Detail

getHead

public static java.awt.Image getHead()
All sprites share the same image object. This is managed as a lazily loaded singleton via this method.

Returns:
the BufferedImage object which contains our sprite image.

getHeadWidth

public static int getHeadWidth()

getHeadHeight

public static int getHeadHeight()

step

public void step()
This method can be called to update the location and velocity of our sprite from frame to frame. It handles collision with the boundary of the animation space by reflecting the sprites velocity at the boundary it has hit. That is if it hits a . vertical boundary it negates the sprite's horizontal velocity, . horizontal bondary it negates the sprite's vertical velocity.

paint

public void paint(java.awt.Graphics pGraphics)
A very simple paint() method - simply draws the sprite image at the sprites current location on the canvas.

Parameters:
pGraphics - the Graphics object on which the sprite image is to be drawn.
